sen.j: 烏帽子親（えぼしおや）とは、元服儀式の際に加冠を行う者のこと。
sen.e: Eboshi-oya was a person who put an eboshi (formal headwear for court nobles) on a young man's head on his genpuku (attainment of manhood) ceremony.

sen.j: 中世武家社会においては、男子が成人に達して元服を行う際に特定の人物に依頼して仮親に為って貰い、当人の頭に烏帽子を被せる役を務めることが通例とされていた。
sen.e: It was a custom in the samurai society in the medieval ages that a special person becomes a nominal father to perform the role of putting an eboshi on a boy's head at his and his family's request when the boy celebrates the genpuku ceremony.

sen.j: この仮親を烏帽子親と呼び、被せられた成人者を烏帽子子と呼んだ。
sen.e: This nominal father was called "eboshi-oya," and the young man who had an eboshi put on his head was called "eboshi-go."
This nominal father was called the "eboshi-oya," and the young man, who was crowned with an eboshi, was called the "eboshi-go."

sen.j: また、この際に童名を廃して、烏帽子親が新たな諱を命名する場合があったその諱を烏帽子名という。
sen.e: Moreover, a new imina (personal name) given by the eboshi-oya was called "eboshi-na," which was given to the boy who abandoned his childhood name at genpuku ceremony.
At that time, the young man abandons his childhood name and a new name, called "eboshi-na," is given to him by the eboshi-oya.

sen.j: 『吾妻鏡』によれば、治承4年10月2日 (旧暦)（1180年10月22日）、源頼朝が乳母である寒河尼の息子（小山朝光）の烏帽子親を務めている。
sen.e: There is a description in "Azuma Kagami" (history book of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)) that MINAMOTO no Yoritomo served as an eboshi-oya of Tomomitsu OYAMA, a son of SAMUKAWA-no-Ama, Yoritomo's wet nurse, on October 22, 1180.

sen.j: このように、烏帽子親には主君や一門の棟梁、信頼の置ける地域の有力者などに委嘱する例が多かった。
sen.e: Thus, lord, toryo (head of the clan), trustworthy local influential person and so on were frequently asked to serve as an eboshi-oya.

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府においては、烏帽子親と烏帽子子は実際の血縁関係が無くてもこれに准じるものとされた。
sen.e: The Kamakura bakufu defined that the relationship between eboshi-oya and eboshi-go is equal to that between real parent and child, even if the former has no blood relation.

sen.j: 文暦2年（1235年）の追加法における評定の際の退座分限（参加禁止者）として親族と並んで烏帽子子が含まれている。
sen.e: The additional laws applied to the main code issued in 1235 prohibited not only relatives but also eboshi-go from attending council.

sen.j: 室町時代以後の元服の儀では烏帽子を被せる代わりに前髪をそり落とす事例が増えた。
sen.e: In the genpuku ceremony held after the Muromachi period, a new system, under which boys had their forelock shaved instead of having eboshi put on their head, were introduced and adopted frequently.

sen.j: それを行うのが烏帽子親の役目とされていた。
sen.e: Shaving boy's forelock was a new role assumed by an eboshi-oya.

sen.j: また、武家社会以外でも王朝時代から続く公家社会での冠礼における引入及び裳着における腰結も仮親による成人儀式であった。
sen.e: Moreover, not only the samurai society but also the court noble society lasting from the period of Heian imperial court had the coming-of-age ceremonies managed by nominal parents similar to the eboshi-oya, who assumed the role of "hiki-ire" (a person who sets young man's hair into a crown) in Kanrei (a ceremony where a man is given a crown for his attainment of manhood) and "koshi-yui" (a person who ties a band around a young woman's waist for her coming-of-age ceremony) in Mogi (coming-of-age ceremony for girls).

sen.j: 近世民間における親方・子方制や女子の鉄漿親（筆親・歯黒親）なども烏帽子親の類似した仮親による成人儀式であった。
sen.e: The general society in the early-modern times also had similar ceremonies by nominal parents, who played the role of "master" in the "Oyakata-kogata-sei" (system of a master and disciples) and "kaneoya" (also called "fudeoya," a women who cares the first black-painting of teeth ceremony of a girl).
